ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course offers a good overview of Hitchcock's films. Plenty of opportunity to practice close film analysis and learn the technical vocabulary.
I learned how interesting it could be to follow the works of a single director!
I wont watch a film the same way again. I now know more what to look for, how to identify themes, and much more.
Learned some degree of film analysis.
Learned a lot about the methods and context of Hitchcocks films

I learned so much from this course! It taught me how to close-read a film, how to write about and discuss film, some of the technical aspects of film, and, most of all, it gave me an in-depth understanding of the films of Alfred Hitchcock and of the scholarship around his work. I will definitely never watch a movie the same way after taking this class.
I learned so much about Film and mise en scene and just like film terminology. I also learned a lot about Hitchcock and a lot of his film techniques.

I learnt about how Hitchcock inspired many other modern films in various genres from horror to romance. I also learnt how to analyze Hitchcock films and other types of films more critically and closely, and how to communicate the analysis in a concise way and with proper film terminology. I also learnt how critical it is to analyze films within the context they are made, considering the other films made during that era and other historical events that could have influenced the reception and analysis of the film.
an understanding of Alfred Hitchcocks films and techniques and his styles

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Great movie list, great readings. I also really enjoyed the weekly film intro on the production/reception.

Weaknesses: I struggled to engage with the discussions at times (although it was over Zoom, so I don't think that was necessarily a weakness of the class in particular)

Strengths: cover many Hitchcock films over a long period of time so it was good to see how Hitchcock's style changed or evolved. 

Weaknesses: discussion sometimes felt difficult to get involved in with a large seminar class sizeespecially over zoom.
This is an excellent course with a well-planned syllabus of different types of Hitchcock films with uniting themes!
Strength is the material. Weakness was the online format. I wish we could have watched the movies together.
This course has interesting content, but the style of construction could have used some work.

I loved this course. Professor Peucker is so knowledgeable and enthusiastic, and our TF, Melinda, was amazing at engaging with students and encouraging them to share their thoughts. I can't think of anything to be improved.
Strengths: Material, and M. Stang was an excellent TF

The Hitchcock movies selected were very engaging and interesting, and the course was well-structured to give an overview of all the different types of movies Hitchcock made during his career as a director. Professor Peucker was also very passionate and knowledgeable, and the class discussions during the lecture were a great way to learn from other students and develop our critical film viewer eye. One of the weaknesses of the course is that drafts are not included to allow more improvement in our film essay writing, but we still received clear feedback on thesis statements and our outlines which helped make our writing more concise.
so interesting and fun!! great discussions and really no weaknesses. Melinda the TF was awesome!!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual seminars in gallery view gave the impression of being like an in-person class!
Online seminar. Breakout rooms might have been fun!
Live lectures are great, but 2 hours is too long.

There are always challenges with working online, but I think the professor and Melinda did a good job of making sure that everyone who wanted to speak could speak, despite so many people being on the Zoom.
I think very accomodating during this difficult time.

The live lecture was engaging, but it was difficult to have spontaneous discussions with such a large group virtually about the significance of certain scenes in Hitchcock movies. The chat feature in zoom was useful in making additional comments and helping facilitate the virtual discussion about the Hitchcock movie being analyzed that week.
Melinda the Teaching Fellow was super helpful with adapting this course to be successful on zoom!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes - great professor, good movies and lively class discussion.
Yes! Great class, I really enjoyed learning about Hitchcock and the world around which he created his films.
Yes, if you're curious about Hitchcock films or enjoy them and want to know more about the production/themes.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! As a STEM major without humanities experience, I gained extremely valuable skills in this class, all the while watching extremely engaging, historically significant films!
Yes! Content is fun and exciting. You get to watch a film every week!

This course was ok. The movies are very interesting and sometimes though provoking. However, the TA's desire to insert her own teaching style distracted from the Professor's efforts to teach. The TA would essentially run a second class discussion via Zoom chat, which was massively distracting and unprofessional. The professor's own lack of control over the chat made the problem worse.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I learned so much about film, and so much about the work of Alfred Hitchcock, with all of its interesting subtext and history. The weekly readings didn't feel like work--I genuinely looked forward to understanding more about each film and what it meant.
Yes, I would it wasn't too much work and super interesting subject matter. But only if you can take it with M. Stang. What an incredible TF.

I would highly recommend this course to any student that loves to watch movies, and wants to learn about the ways that Hitchcock inspired many movies we watch today. This course equips students with the skills to more closely analyze any movie, and consider the ways that the historical and societal context impact the way the film was made, and highlight the significance of certain scenes.

I would not recommend this class. I say that not because the class was necessarily terrible, but simply because it was not what it was advertised to be. The class was called "The Films of Alfred Hitchcock," but a more appropriate title would have been "The Films of Alfred Hitchcock as Misinterpreted by the Excessive Use of Feminist and Freudian Analysis." I hoped to study the directing style of Hitchcock and the cinematic elements of his work, as I assumed was to be taught in a film class that focused exclusively on his work. What I experienced instead was an extensive discussion about a bunch of freudian concepts which were both out of date and entirely unrelated to the actual subject matter of the films. I admit that in the case of "Marnie" and "Psycho" the obsessive focus on freudian psychology was justified, but in regards to the other films I think it was entirely out of place. I also think the focus on feminism was a bit intense, and received more attention than it deserved. In general, I was disappointed by the fact that the class was more about feminism and freudian psychology than it was about film.
yes!! it was so much fun and i learned so much. Definitely take this class!!!!
For anyone with an interest in Hitchcock, or films generally, this is a great class. You will be sure to find many other cinephiles like yourself.
